newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SIMEX Nikkei futures head south in slow trade.
newsitem.headline: SIMEX Nikkei futures head south in slow trade.

text.p: SIMEX Nikkei futures drifted off by the close of a slow Monday session, which saw activity confined to a relatively narrow range amid a dearth of leads.
The benchmark Nikkei 225 March contract lost 170 points to end at 18,150 on light volume of 14,135 lots.

Dealers said the cash market's wait-and-see stance ahead of a land auction by a former Japanese state-owned railway firm in the afternoon and the dollar's uncertain outlook before a meeting of finance ministers from the Group of Seven (G7) nations this week also hampered participation.

A Japanese newspaper reported on Sunday that Japan would ask the G7 to help curb the yen's sharp fall against the dollar, but dealers were skeptical about the potential for a dollar decline. "Most people are bullish about the dollar. I still see it going to 125 yen," said a trader with a Japanese house. The dollar was quoted at 121.45/55 yen in afternoon Tokyo trade.

"Not that many people are willing to buy the Nikkei. Even if it goes above resistance at 18,400, I don't think we'll see the panic buying we saw last week," said the trader. "I'm still willing to go short."
He said investors would want to cash in their gains on any rallies ahead of the Japanese financial year end on March 31.
"If it closes above 18,500, we could see it higher to 18,750 but that looks tough. Hopefully, it'll stay above 18,000," said a trader with a local institution.
The March MSCI Taiwan index contract ended at 315.9 against its opening 316.5 on turnover of 62 lots.
